natural solution: We can represent the sum as \[\sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n(1988 - n).\]This is equal to \begin{align} \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} (1988n - n^2) &= 1988 \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n - \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n^2 \\ &= 1988 \cdot \frac{1987 \cdot 1988}{2} - \frac{1987 \cdot 1988 \cdot 3975}{6} \\

\[1 \cdot 1987 + 2 \cdot 1986 + 3 \cdot 1985 + \dots + 1986 \cdot 2 + 1987 \cdot 1 = 1987 \cdot 994 \cdot x,\]compute the integer $x.$ The final Answer is 663

 We can represent the sum as \[\sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n(1988 - n).\]This is equal to \begin{align} \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} (1988n - n^2) &= 1988 \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n - \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n^2 \\ &= 1988 \cdot \frac{1987 \cdot 1988}{2} - \frac{1987 \cdot 1988 \cdot 3975}{6} \\

 *)

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 1987 \<longrightarrow> f n = n * (1988 - n)"
and h1 : "sum f {1..1987} = 1987 * 994 * x"
shows  "x = 663"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If
\[1 \cdot 1987 + 2 \cdot 1986 + 3 \cdot 1985 + \dots + 1986 \cdot 2 + 1987 \cdot 1 = 1987 \cdot 994 \cdot x,\]compute the integer $x.$ The final Answer is 663
 ### Proof
 We can represent the sum as \[\sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n(1988 - n).\]This is equal to \begin{align} \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} (1988n - n^2) &= 1988 \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n - \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n^2 \\ &= 1988 \cdot \frac{1987 \cdot 1988}{2} - \frac{1987 \cdot 1988 \cdot 3975}{6} \\
 &= \frac{1987 \cdot 1988}{6} (3 \cdot 1988 - 3975) \\ &= \frac{1987 \cdot 2 \cdot 994}{6} \cdot 1989 \\ &= \frac{1987 \cdot 994}{3} \cdot 1989 \\ &= 1987 \cdot 994 \cdot 663. \end{align}Thus, $x = \boxed{663}.$
 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 1987 \<longrightarrow> f i = (1988 - i) * i"
and h1 : "sum f {1..1987} = 1987 * 994 * x"

(* ### Problem

\[1 \cdot 1987 + 2 \cdot 1986 + 3 \cdot 1985 + \dots + 1986 \cdot 2 + 1987 \cdot 1 = 1987 \cdot 994 \cdot x,\]compute the integer $x.$ The final Answer is 663
 ### Proof
 We can represent the sum as \[\sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n(1988 - n).\]This is equal to \begin{align} \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} (1988n - n^2) &= 1988 \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n - \sum_{n = 1}^{1987} n^2 \\ &= 1988 \cdot \frac{1987 \cdot 1988}{2} - \frac{1987 \cdot 1988 \cdot 3975}{6} \\
 &= \frac{1987 \cdot 1988}{6} (3 \cdot 1988 - 3975) \\ &= \frac{1987 \cdot 2 \cdot 994}{6} \cdot 1989 \\ &= \frac{1987 \cdot 994}{3} \cdot 1989 \\ &= 1987 \cdot 994 \cdot 663. \end{align}Thus, $x = \boxed{663}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 1987 \<longrightarrow> f i = (1988 - i) * i"
and h1 : "sum f {1..1987} = 1987 * 994 * x"
shows  "x = 663"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: For all integers $i$ ranging from 1 to 1987, a function $f(i) = (1988 - i) * i$ is defined. If the sum of the function $f$ evaluated from 1 to 1987 is $1987 * 994 * x$, what is the value of $x$? The final answer is $663$.
